"
1. Isolate FMD infected cattle to prevent transmission of the virus to other livestock.
2. Give vitamin and ATP supplement
3. Give Antipyretic (reduce body temperature) and Analgesic (reduce pain)
4. Encourage infected cattle to keep eating even if appetite decreases
5. Give medicine and vitamins repeatedly until the cow recovers
 "

"
 Oops! Your cow has FMD ðŸ˜¥
 Based on the picture you uploaded, the cow has Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD). You can follow the tips below to prevent the disease from spreading further.
 "
"\n Don't panic and worry! You can do the above treatments then do regular maintenance and check the condition of the cattle by utilizing the SnapMoo app!\n "

"
1. Maintain feed quality
2. Maintain cleanliness of the cage environment
3. Maintain the immune system of livestock
 "

"
Wow, your cow is not infected with FMD!
Let's apply these tips to maintain cattle health and avoid FMD!
 "
"\n Maintain your cow's health by regularly checking the cow's condition. You can use the scan feature on the SnapMoo application regularly!\n "
Symptoms of FMD in the Foot

Open sores and inflammation around the nail. The area around the nail looks red, swollen, and inflamed. These open wounds can be caused by trauma, infection, or other health conditions. From the open wound, there is often a discharge of pus or exudate indicating that an infection has occurred.

A blister bursts and becomes an erosion of the skin around the nail. A blister, caused by friction or infection, contains clear fluid or pus. When the blister bursts it leaves an area of erosion that is prone to infection. Erosions are often found in the area between the toes (interdigital), where moisture and friction are more common.

Swelling around the nail area. Swelling (edema) occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in the tissues around the nail. This area appears enlarged, shiny, and may feel warm to the touch. Swelling may cause discomfort and interfere with the normal functioning of the foot.
Animals show difficulty walking and obvious pain when walking. They may limp, avoid using the affected leg, or show obvious pain when the affected leg touches the ground.
The above symptoms can be caused by various conditions such as bacterial or fungal infections, physical trauma, allergies, or systemic diseases.
Treatment of FMD Symptoms in the Foot
Cleaning the wound with an antiseptic to prevent further infection.
Administering appropriate antibiotics or antifungals based on the cause of infection.
Protecting the wound from dirt and reducing the risk of infection by using a bandage or wound dressing.
Consultation with a veterinarian or FMD Task Force for proper diagnosis and effective treatment.
Consult a veterinarian for a proper diagnosis and appropriate treatment recommendations.
Sign in to Protect Your Cattle
Symptoms of FMD in the Mouth

There are blisters that burst into sores on the gums and tongue. These blisters are filled with fluid which is very painful for the animal. After some time, the blisters burst and turn into open wounds which are also prone to infection.

Excessive saliva production. This excessive saliva is usually thick in texture and can be seen dripping continuously from the animal\'s mouth. This occurs due to irritation and sores in the mouth that stimulate the salivary glands to produce more saliva as a pain response.

cattle show difficulty and pain when eating. Animals infected with FMD often show signs of feeding difficulties, such as chewing slowly, stopping frequently while eating, refusing food, and loss of appetite.

Strong, unpleasant bad breath. This odor is caused by bacteria that multiply around wounds and dead tissue, as well as metabolic products produced by the bacteria. This bad breath is a sign that there is a serious infection in the animal\'s mouth..
Treatment of FMD Symptoms in the Mouth
Isolate infected animals to prevent the spread of the virus to other animals
Focus on reducing pain and supporting recovery. Analgesics and anti-inflammatories may be used to reduce pain and inflammation.
Clean wounds in the mouth with antiseptic to prevent secondary infection.
Provide foods that are soft and easy to chew to reduce pain while eating.
Steps for Handling Cattle Positive for FMD
How many livestock do you have?
Enter a description of the condition of your cattle (optional)
Your Partner in Ensuring a Healthy and Happy Cattle Herd
Too many farmers are surprised and realize too late how deadly FMD can be
FMD Symptoms: Focus on Body Parts
Symptoms of FMD in the Udder

Drastic reduction in milk production. Cows affected by FMD experience severe physical stress and pain, as well as decreased appetite and nutrient intake. As a result, the cow\'s body is unable to produce the usual amount of milk, often reducing milk production by more than 50%.

Milk becomes thinner or frothy. The milk produced by the cow becomes thinner than usual. Milk also foams due to changes in the biochemical composition of the milk due to viral infection. These changes can make the milk unfit for consumption.

Blisters and sores occur on the nipples. These blisters are filled with fluid and are very painful for the cow. When the blisters burst, it leaves an open wound that is prone to infection. These sores cause pain which often causes the cow to refuse to milk.
Treatment of FMD Symptoms in the Udder
Symptomatic treatment aimed at reducing pain and supporting recovery.
Nipple wounds should be cleaned regularly and treated with antiseptic to prevent infection.
Provide adequate nutrition to support the animal\'s immune system.
